newsitem.title: ROMANIA: U.S. SHAPIRO GETS 40 PCT IN ROMANIA BIOFARM.
newsitem.headline: U.S. SHAPIRO GETS 40 PCT IN ROMANIA BIOFARM.

text.p: U.S. banking firm Shapiro & Co acquired 40 percent of Romania's Biofarm pharmaceuticals and pledged to invest $50 million in expanding the company, the State Ownership Fund (FPS) said on Wednesday.
"The contract was signed several weeks ago and Shapiro will pay for the whole stake in about 40 days after the signing," FPS president Sorin Dimitriu told a news conference.
The selling price remained confidential but Dimitriu said the FPS had got 30 percent more than it had bargained for.

Biofarm, which holds a share of about 25 percent of the local market for pharmaceuticals, has a capital of nine billion lei. The FPS was a 40 percent shareholder, with the remaining 60 percent held by Romanian individuals who bought shares with vouchers in a mass selloff.
Shapiro's investment package for Biofarm starts this month, Dimitriu said.

"Shapiro will invest in boosting capacity and in bringing Romanian pharmaceuticals in line with European standards so that exports will be possible," Shapiro lawyer David Ben Yehuda Costa told reporters.
It will also invest in environmental protection.

Shapiro, based in Carson City, Nevada, has shares in chemical and petrochemical companies in Italy, Switzerland and the United States, a company statement said. No further information on Shapiro was immediately available.
The company was planning to make other strategic investments in Romania's chemical and petrochemical sectors.
Biofarm trades on Romania's over-the-counter market and its shareholders' meeting had agreed to move it on to the Bucharest bourse prior to the sale to Shapiro.
"For the time being, we are not interested in taking the company to the stock exchange. It will continue to trade on the OTC market," Costa said. ($=7,433 lei)
